sub_topic: The study of the properties of the Higgs boson in different decay modes.
message_1: "What are the decay channels of the Higgs boson and how can its properties be studied through these channels?"
message_2:
The Higgs boson is an elementary particle in the Standard Model of particle physics, responsible for giving other particles mass through the Higgs mechanism. It was discovered in 2012 at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN. The Higgs boson is unstable and decays into other particles almost immediately after being produced. These decay channels are crucial for studying the properties of the Higgs boson, as they provide experimental signatures that can be detected and analyzed.

The main decay channels of the Higgs boson are:

1. Higgs to bottom quark-antiquark pair (H → bb): This is the most common decay channel, with a branching ratio of about 58%. The Higgs boson decays into a bottom quark and its corresponding antiquark.

2. Higgs to W boson pair (H → WW): With a branching ratio of about 21%, the Higgs boson can decay into a pair of W bosons, which can be either W+ and W- or a virtual W boson pair.

3. Higgs to Z boson pair (H → ZZ): This decay channel has a branching ratio of about 2.6%. The Higgs boson decays into a pair of Z bosons, which can be either on-shell or off-shell (virtual).

4. Higgs to tau lepton-antilepton pair (H → ττ): The Higgs boson can decay into a tau lepton and its corresponding antilepton, with a branching ratio of about 6.3%.

5. Higgs to charm quark-antiquark pair (H → cc): This decay channel has a branching ratio of about 2.9%. The Higgs boson decays into a charm quark and its corresponding antiquark.

6. Higgs to gluon pair (H → gg): With a branching ratio of about 8.6%, the Higgs boson can decay into a pair of gluons through a loop of top quarks.

7. Higgs to photon pair (H → γγ): This is a rare decay channel, with a branching ratio of about 0.2%. The Higgs boson decays into two photons through a loop of W bosons or top quarks.

8. Higgs to muon-antimuon pair (H → μμ): This is an extremely rare decay channel, with a branching ratio of about 0.02%. The Higgs boson decays into a muon and its corresponding antimuon.

The properties of the Higgs boson, such as its mass, spin, and couplings to other particles, can be studied through these decay channels. By analyzing the decay products and their energy distributions, physicists can infer the properties of the Higgs boson and test the predictions of the Standard Model. The LHC experiments, ATLAS and CMS, have observed several of these decay channels, providing crucial evidence for the existence of the Higgs boson and helping to refine our understanding of its properties.
